IMAGE-HIGH-RES MOLCAA 10102 S1381-1169(16)30461-7 10.1016/j.molcata.2016.11.005 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 TGA/DTA curves of as prepared precursors for (1a) CoFe2O4, (1b) FeCo2O4, (1c) Co3O4. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD diffractograms of bulk and supported calcined solids. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 phase diagram of the system CoFe2O4/Co3O4 (S. Hirano and coll. [21]). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of (4a) CP-Co1-500 and IMP-Co1-500, (4b) CP-Co2-500 and IMP-Co2-500, (4c) CP-Co3-500 and IMP-Co3-500. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 TPR profiles of bulk and supported calcined solids. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Ethanol conversion as function of reaction temperature over bulk and supported catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Variation in yield of the partial oxidation products over CP-Co1-500 and IMP-Co1-500 samples. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Arrhenius plots and illustration of the compensation effect for the ethanol combustion reaction catalyzed by the bulk and supported spinel oxides CoFe2O4, FeCo2O4 and Co3O4. Fig. 8 Table 1 Cristallite size, BET surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of the bulk and supported catalysts. Table 1 Solid Crystallite size (nm) SBET (m2/g) Vpores (cm3/g) Dpores (nm) SiO2 – 211 – – CP-Co1-500 8.5 62.2 0.21 13.44 CP-Co2-500 8.7 60.08 0.19 23.26 CP-Co3-500 9.5 42.7 0.22 18.46 IMP-Co1-500 ND 172 0.23 5.48 IMP-Co2-500 13.75 163 0.22 5.46 IMP-Co3-500 9.94 152 0.22 5.78 ND: not determined. Table 2 Temperature values of ethanol isoconversion over bulk and supported cobalt oxide and cobalt ferrite catalysts. Table 4 Catalyst CP-Co1- 500 CP-Co2-500 CP-Co3-500 IMP-Co1-500 IMP-Co2-500 IMP-Co3-500 Ea (Kj/mol) 47.4 61.2 26.7 37.7 76.9 50.8 ln A 13.4 15.9 5.9 10.3 20.8 14.2 Cobalt and cobalt-iron spinel oxides as bulk and silica supported catalysts in the ethanol combustion reaction Yasmina Hammiche-Bellal a ⁎ Nabila Zouaoui-Mahzoul b Ibtissem Lounas c Amel Benadda a Rafik Benrabaa a Aline Auroux d Laaldja Meddour-Boukhobza a Amar Djadoun e a Laboratoire des Matériaux Catalytiques et Catalyse en Chimie Organique, Faculté de Chimie, USTHB, BP32 El Alia, Bab Ezzouar, 16111, Alger, Algérie Laboratoire des Matériaux Catalytiques et Catalyse en Chimie Organique Faculté de Chimie USTHB BP32 El Alia Bab Ezzouar Alger 16111 Algérie b Laboratoire Gestion des Risques et Environnement (LGRE, EA2334), Institut de Recherche Jean-Baptiste Donnet, Université de Haute-Alsace, 3bis rue Alfred Werner, 68093 Mulhouse Cedex, France Laboratoire Gestion des Risques et Environnement (LGRE, EA2334) Institut de Recherche Jean-Baptiste Donnet Université de Haute-Alsace 3bis rue Alfred Werner Mulhouse Cedex 68093 France c Laboratoire de Chimie du Gaz Naturel, Faculté de Chimie, USTHB, BP32 El Alia, Bab Ezzouar, 16111, Alger, Algérie Laboratoire de Chimie du Gaz Naturel Faculté de Chimie USTHB BP32 El Alia Bab Ezzouar Alger 16111 Algérie d Université Lyon 1, CNRS, UMR 5256, IRCELYON, Institut de Recherches sur la Catalyse et l’Environnement de Lyon, 2 Avenue Albert Einstein, F-69626 Villeurbanne, France Université Lyon 1 CNRS UMR 5256 IRCELYON Institut de Recherches sur la Catalyse et l’Environnement de Lyon 2 Avenue Albert Einstein Villeurbanne F-69626 France e Laboratoire de Géophysique, FSTGAT, USTHB, BP32 El Alia Bab Ezzouar 16111, Alger, Algérie Laboratoire de Géophysique FSTGAT USTHB BP32 El Alia Bab Ezzouar Alger 16111 Algérie ⁎ *Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Cobalt and mixed iron-cobalt spinel oxides CoxFe(3-x)O4 supported on SiO2 ‘IMP-Cox-500′ and their bulk analogues ‘CP-Cox-500′ were prepared via impregnation and co-precipitation methods respectively and calcined at 500°C. Thermogravimetric analysis ‘ATG/DTG’, X-ray Diffraction method ‘XRD’, Texture measurements ‘BET/BJH’ and Temperature Programmed Reduction technique ‘TPR’ were used for their characterization. Their catalytic behavior in ethanol combustion was investigated. Results showed that nanostructured oxide materials with spinel structure were obtained with a good dispersion of the active phase at the surface of silica in the case of IMP-Cox-500 compounds. The reduction behavior of the prepared samples is highly dependent on the oxide composition and interaction with the support; which is directly related to the catalytic behavior. The use of supported catalysts improves the catalytic performance and leads the reaction towards a total oxidation by decreasing greatly the formation of partial oxidation products. The obtained values of activation energies are relatively low in comparison with the literature data. A compensation effect was found by carrying out ethanol combustion through the spinel systems considered in this work. Keywords Spinel oxides Precipitation Impregnation Ethanol combustion 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are a large group of carbon-based chemicals that easily evaporate at room temperature as alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, halogenated hydrocarbons, aromatics, alkanes, etc [1]. VOCs are classified as pollutants; they are toxic and contribute significantly to the formation of the photochemical smog, which has remarkable impact to the air quality [2]. Regulations on air quality have been implemented to control VOCs in many countries such as the European Union, the United States of America and China [3,4]. VOCs originate from many places such as biogenic sources, solvents, industrial products and automobile emissions. The main sources of VOCs are vehicles; they are accounting for 32% of the total VOCs mass in USA and 35% in Europe [5]. Formation of vehicle emissions comes from the combustion process and evaporation of the fuel. Ethanol is a renewable fuel that can be used as an additive to gasoline or its substitute, with the advantage of octane enhancement and reduced carbon monoxide exhaust emissions [6,7]. However, the exhaust from vehicles fed with such fuel contains residue of unburned alcohol and some of its partially oxidized derivatives such as aldehydes and ketones, so it is important to evaluate the catalytic performance in ethanol combustion. Catalytic combustion is one of the most important and attractive technologies for reducing volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emissions due to its many advantages, such as high efficiency, low operating temperatures and extremely low emissions of NOx and unreacted hydrocarbons [8]. Transition metal oxides are an inexpensive alternative to conventional catalysts based on noble metals, which are highly active but rather expensive. Furthermore, they are susceptible to deactivation by poisoning, especially in the presence of water, one of the combustion products [9,10]. As reported in literature, mixed oxides of transition metals present more favorable properties compared to single-metal oxides which make them more active and more resistant to deactivation [11–16]. Ferrite oxides have been widely studied, and it is well established that ferrites properties depend strongly on the nature and amount of the substituting metal and also its position in the crystalline structure, [17,18]. Recently, catalytic properties of MeFe2O4 spinel ferrites (Me=Cu, Cd, Ni, Zn and Co) in the VOCs combustion were evidenced, opening a new field of application for these materials [19,20]. Particularly, the cobalt spinel ferrite CoFe2O4 showed the best reactivity among the studied ferrites in the total oxidation of ethanol. In this work, we propose a comparative study between bulk and supported CoxFe(3-x)O4 catalysts (x=1,2,3). the aim is to (i) examine the effect of the structural phase composition of iron-cobalt spinel and the effect of the use of silica support on the catalytic properties of the developed solids (ii) correlate the physico-chemical characteristics to the catalytic activity in the total oxidation of ethanol. From the phase diagram of the CoFe2O4-Co3O4 system, the thermal stability of the spinel phase CoxFe(3-x)O4 is closely related to its composition and cobalt oxide Co3O4 and cobalt ferrite CoFe2O4 present stable single spinel phases up to 900 and 1300°C respectively [21]. Contrarily, the iron cobaltite FeCo2O4 exists as a single-phase spinel only in the temperature range 850–950°C. Below 850°C, the iron cobaltite undergoes spinodal decomposition in two average compositional spinel phases approaching the CoFe2O4 and Co3O4 spinel oxides. The synthesis of these materials is widely reported in the literature and has been used in different applications such as photodegradation of dyes, catalytic and lithium storage properties [22–25]. In this work, we adopted the co-precipitation method for the synthesis of bulk powders and the incipient wetness impregnation method for the preparation of supported catalysts. The so-prepared materials were characterized by X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, surface area measurements and temperature-programmed reduction. Their catalytic activities were evaluated in the reaction of ethanol combustion. 2 Experimental 2.1 Samples preparation Iron nitrate Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (Fluka, 99%) and cobalt nitrate Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Merck, 99%) were used as precursor salts, sodium hydroxide as precipitating agent and silica SiO2 (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.5%, 211m2/g) as support. For the preparation of bulk catalysts, precursor salts were weighted in the adequate molar ratios Co/Fe and dissolved in double-distilled water. NaOH aqueous solution (2M) was added till pH=12 under constant stirring at room temperature. After filtering and repeated washing with double-distilled water, the precipitates were dried at 80°C for 12h and then calcined at 500°C for 5h with a heating rate of 10°C/min. The as-prepared precursors are named CP-Cox and the calcined samples CP-Cox-500 (x=1, 2, 3). The wet impregnation method was employed to synthesize the CoxFe(3-x)O4/SiO2 catalysts with 10wt.% CoxFe(3-x)O4 phase. They were prepared by impregnating the silica powder with aqueous solutions containing the required amounts of precursor salts. The solutions were stirred constantly at 80°C up to a maximum water evaporation. The obtained samples were dried at 80°C for 12h and calcined at 500°C for 5h with a heating rate of 10°C/min. The resulting powders will be named IMP-Cox-500 (x=1, 2, 3). 2.2 Characterization techniques Thermogravimetric analysis (ATG/DTG) of the solids was performed in a SETARAM TG-DTA12 system; samples were heated from 25 to 900°C, at a heating rate of 10°C/min, in flowing Argon. The X-ray Diffraction (XRD) pattern analysis was carried out with Cu Kα radiation, using a Philips X-ray diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator. The XRD patterns were recorded in the 2θ range of 10°–90° with a scanning step of 0.02° and a counting time of 1s. The crystalline phases of the prepared solids were identified by comparison with the JCPDS files. The unit cell parameter was obtained using Rietveld analysis of the powder XRD data (Xpowder 2004.04.59 Pro software). The mean crystallite sizes of the phases detected by XRD were determined from the broadening of the line of attributed peaks using the Williamson-Hall method. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded on a Micromeritics ASAP 2010. Prior analysis, the samples were out gassed overnight under vacuum at 623K. The Specific surface areas were determined from the adsorption-desorption data by BET procedure and the pore size distributions by BJH method. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) analyses were carried out in a TPD/R/O-1100 instrument (Thermo-Fisher), using H2/Ar (5% v/v) as reducing gas mixture, flowing at 20mLmin−1. The reduction behavior of the samples was studied in the range 40–1000°C at a heating rate of 5°Cmin−1, and sample weights were chosen according to literature recommendations [26,27] to improve the resolution of the peaks. 2.3 Catalytic activity and kinetic factors determination The catalytic activity of the solids was evaluated in the total oxidation of ethanol using a glass fixed bed reactor (30cm long, Φinner=1cm). Prior to catalytic tests, solids were activated by heating in flowing air up to 300°C for 15min, to remove any eventual physisorbed water molecules. Air was used as carrier gas for ethanol vapor and as oxidant reactant. The catalyst (0.2g, catalytic bed height about 2mm) was tested under a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 30m3 h − 1 kg − 1 in the temperature range 125–350°C. The reactant mixture was analyzed using a Clarus500 Perkin-Elmer chromatograph equipped with a FID detector and a 20% carbowax/Chromosorb packed column. Each temperature has been maintained for 90min during which several analysis of the reaction mixture have been performed. The conversion of ethanol, X%, is defined as the percentage of ethanol feed that has reacted, the reported values were calculated after stationary regime was reached, by the following relation: X (%)=[(Ai −Ar)/Ai]×100 ‘Ai’ and ‘Ar’ are the ethanol chromatographic peaks areas in the reactional mixture before and after passing through the reactor respectively. The calculation of selectivity (Si%) and yield (Yi%) was performed for the partial oxidation products of ethanol, which may be formed during the reaction of ethanol with oxygen, according to the relation: Si (%)=(ni/reacted nT)×100 ‘ni’ is the moles number of the product i, ‘reacted nT’ is the total moles number of all reaction products. Y%=[X (%) * Si (%)]/100 The specific reaction rate (V), expressed per gram of catalyst per unit time (s) is calculated as follows [28]: V=(C * F)/m for low rate conversions C<0.2 V=(F/m) * (1−C) * Ln (1/(1-C) for conversion of C>0.2 C=Conversion rate F=ethanol flow=1.085μmol/s m: mass of the active phase in the catalyst (0.2g for a bulk catalyst, 0.02g for a supported catalyst) To access the values of the apparent activation energies (Eapp) from the values of specific reaction rate, the following classical equation was used: LnV=(−Eapp/RT)+Ln Aapp Aapp: apparent Arrhenius constant. 3 Results 3.1 Characterization of the bulk catalysts The thermal decomposition of the precursor powders was examined by TGA/DTA (Fig. 1 a–c). The curves obtained show basically three main mass losses associated respectively with: • An endothermic step in the temperature interval 100–200°C attributed to removal of physisorbed and chemisorbed water • An exothermic peak situated between 300 and 500°C, it corresponds to the decomposition of metal precursors giving rise to the corresponding oxides CoO and Fe2O3 [7]. • An endothermic decomposition at about 850°C in the case of CP-Co2 sample. This phenomenon reflects the transformation of the two-phase system in a single-phase system in accordance with XRD results exposed below. The X-ray diffractograms of the calcined samples are represented in Fig. 2 . The solids CP-Co1-500 and CP-Co3-500 exhibit characteristic peaks of the spinel phases CoFe2O4 and Co3O4 respectively (F3dm space group). On the other hand, XRD profiles of the CP-Co2-500 powder display also the existence of diffraction peaks positioned at 2θ angles consistent with a spinel phase but they are splitted when calcination temperature ranges between 600 and 800°C, implying the presence of two distinct spinel phases; one rich in iron and the second rich in cobalt, in agreement with the phase diagram, shown in Fig. 3 , established by S. Hirano and coll. [21]. Indeed, the composition of the oxides obtained in the temperature range 600–800°C, are in the miscibility gap in which the material exists in the form of two spinel phases. Furthermore, the monophasic structure shown by the diffractogram of the sample calcined at 900°C is in agreement with the phase diagram; this solid is well located in the spinel single-phase domain. Note that the spinel species CoFe2O4 and Co3O4 are stable till 1300 and 900°C respectively. The values of crystallite size of the calcined solids are listed in Table 1 , they are varying between 8.5 and 9.5nm. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distributions are shown in Fig. 4 , the textural properties are listed in Table 1. The isotherms are of type IV with a clear H1-type hysteretic loop, which are characteristic of mesoporous materials. The mixed oxides CP-Co1-500 and CP-Co2-500 have a pore volume of 0.21 and 0.19cm3 g−1 respectively and a similar surface area of about 60m2g−1 which are greater than those of the single oxide having a surface area of 42.7m2 g−1 and a pore volume of 0.22cm3g−1. The pore size distribution curves show that the pure spinel oxides CP-Co1-500 and CP-Co3-500 have a very narrow pore size distribution ranging between 10 and 30nm while the solid CP-Co2-500 has a wider distribution pore size ranging from 10 to 90nm. In order to investigate the reduction behavior of the prepared samples, H2-TPR analysis was performed. The TPR profiles of the calcined samples are shown in Fig. 5 . As it can be seen, the shape of the profiles is similar for all of them but reduction take place at different temperatures. It can be observed that the peaks maxima of H2 consumption for the mixed oxides were shifted to higher temperatures compared to the cobalt oxide reduction peaks, this result is similar to those reported in the literature [29]. The pure cobalt oxide sample (Co/Fe=1/0) has been shown to be constituted by mainly Co3O4 phase, with a TPR profile displaying two main peaks. The first peak at 315°C corresponds to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and the second peak at 370°C is related to the reduction of CoO to Co0 [30,31]. The CP-Co1-500 sample revealed four reduction peaks that were identified in our previous study [32] according to literature Data. The reduction peaks at lower temperatures (328 and 396°C) correspond to the more easily reducible cations (in this case Co3+ and Co2+) [33], present in the form of cobalt oxide phases [34]. The last two peaks at 463 and 518°C are assigned to the successive reduction of Fe3+ and Fe2+ oxides species, corresponding to the reduction sequences: Fe2O3 →Fe3O4 →Fe [35]. The TPR plot of the solid CP-Co2-500 showed three reduction steps at 398, 444 and 523°C respectively. According to the results previously obtained for the cobalt ferrite, the peaks at 398 and 523°C are attributed to the reduction of cobalt species, the last peak at higher temperature result from the reduction of ferric ions. One can observe that the reduction temperatures of CP-Co2-500 are relatively higher than those of CP-Co1-500 meaning that FeCo2O4 phase was more difficult to be reduced than CoFe2O4 phase. Generally, the shift of the reduction curves to higher temperature can be ascribed to an increase in the crystallite size [33,36,37]. However, the samples CP-Co2-500 and CP-Co1-500 revealed similar crystallite size and surface area values as shown in Table 1. So, their reducibility could be assigned to different metal Fe–Co interactions in catalysts structures which may reshape the TPR profile [37]. 3.2 Characterization of the supported catalysts X-ray diffraction patterns obtained with the support and the supported catalysts are shown in Fig. 2. The silicon oxide material manifests an amorphous structure throughout the considered diffraction field. The position of the observed peaks for the supported catalysts confirmed that spinel phases are present in all the samples and the support remained unchanged after metal impregnation and calcination step. As listed in Table 1, the crystallite size of IMP-Co1-500 cannot be determined by the Williamson-Hall method because of the poorly crystalline phase obtained. Recently, Bragança et al. reported the synthesis and characterization of Co-Fe nanoparticles supported on mesoporous silica [38,39]. They have found that diffraction peak positions were observed through characteristic lines of Co3O4 crystalline phase for monometallic cobalt based catalyst, while diffraction peaks for the Co-Fe/SiO2 samples indicated the presence of two phases; Co3O4 and CoFe2O4 spinel oxides. In this work a similar result was obtained for IMP-Co3-500 sample which showed a well crystallized Co3O4 phase whose diffraction angles are perfectly consistent with those reported in JCPDS file 421467. For bimetallic iron-cobalt based catalysts, only lines corresponding to spinel phases have been clearly indentified. Nevertheless, the presence of secondary phases, namely cobalt spinel oxide Co3O4 and hematite Fe2O3, cannot be excluded but their identification is not obvious due to small proportions. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the supported catalysts are revealed in Fig. 4. Textural data, reported in Table 1, show an important increase in the specific surface area compared to bulk catalysts; the values obtained are between 152 and 172m2 g−1. The shape of the adsorption-desorption isotherms approaches the type IV isotherm with a H3 hysteresis loop indicating the formation of slit-like mesopores. The supported catalysts were subjected to a temperature programmed reduction under the same experimental conditions as bulk catalysts. This analysis allowed us to examine the influence of the support on the redox properties of the materials investigated. TPR profiles obtained are shown in Fig. 5. A clear shift of the reduction curves is observed for supported catalysts as compared to the bulk ones. In addition to the reduction peaks corresponding to cobalt and iron oxide species previously identified in the study of the bulk solids, the TPR profiles of the supported catalysts show the presence of peaks, at higher temperatures, related to the reduction of the spinel phase interacting with the support. This interaction is of electrostatic type between silanol groups present on the silica surface and the metal cations [40,41]. The reduction peaks occur at the temperatures maxima 849, 822 and 688°C for IMP-Co1-SiO2, IMP-Co2-SiO2 and IMP-Co3-SiO2 respectively. The peaks of the supported materials are much broader than the bulk ones, which confirm the existence of a wide particle size distribution as shown by the BJH analysis [36]. The reduction sequences of IMP-Co2-500 take place at lower temperatures than those observed for IMP-Co1-500 sample; this may be due to the higher proportion of cobalt in the former solid. Indeed, Xiangdong Ma et al. [42] observed that the TPR profiles of Fe-Co/SiO2 were shifted toward the lower temperatures when the cobalt content increased; this was interpreted in terms of reducibility enhancement by cobalt species in the Fe-Co/SiO2 catalyst. 3.3 Catalytic activities and reaction kinetics Fig. 6 displays catalytic activity results for the ethanol combustion reaction over the bulk and supported catalysts. Depending on the solid composition, ethanol combustion via the bulk catalysts started at about 150–200°C and full conversion of ethanol was achieved between 275 and 350°C. As expected, the activity of the mixed oxides CoFe2O4 and FeCo2O4 is generally better than that of the single oxide Co3O4. For a conversion below 15%, the three oxides have the same reactivity, in contrast to higher conversion levels, where the reactivity closely depends on the solid composition. Cobalt ferrite exhibits significantly the best activity; a conversion jump from 30 to about 100% is obtained via the CP-Co1-500 sample in the temperature range 250–275°C. The activity of iron cobaltite is intermediary between cobalt ferrite CoFe2O4 and cobalt oxide Co3O4; 90% of ethanol is converted at 300°C over CP-Co2-500 catalyst against only 50% on CP-Co3-500 sample, this latter solid achieved a total conversion at about 350°C. The catalytic performances of the supported solids are greatly different from that of bulk catalysts. Reactivity is substantially similar, for all the solids, till 30% of conversion. Further than, the conversion reached 96, 77 and 60% at 275°C, for the samples IMP-Co2-500, IMP-Co3-500 and IMP-Co1-500 respectively. Yields of ethanol partial oxidation products were calculated and illustrated in Fig. 7 for the solids CP-Co1-500 and IMP-Co1-500. For all the tested bulk catalysts, the secondary product detected corresponds to acetaldehyde, which is quite significant at low temperature and rather small at high temperature. The second partial oxidation product is acetic acid, present in lower amounts in the whole considered temperature range. On the supported catalysts, the partial oxidation products are present at very low levels in the total studied temperature range, indicating that the supported catalysts orient preferentially the reaction towards a total oxidation even at low temperatures. Because of the small proportion of spinel phase in the supported catalysts (a supported catalyst contains only 10% of spinel phase), comparing reactivity by means of conversion is not significant, the determination of specific reaction rates is essential. Their values, expressed per gram of spinel phase per unit time, permit a meaningful comparison of bulk and supported catalysts activities. The determination of the specific reaction rates was performed by applying the relations previously mentioned in section 1.c. The calculations were made at ethanol conversions below 30%. The values obtained are summarized in Table 3 . The determination of apparent activation energies and Arrhenius prefactors was performed by plotting the curves lnV=f (1/T) as shown in Fig. 8 . The slope of the line is ‘-Ea/R’ and the intercept represents the apparent values of ‘In A’; the values obtained are summarized in Table 4 . The apparent activation energies vary from 26.7kJ/mol (over CP-Co3-500) to 76.9kJ/mol (over IMP-Co2-500). Note that the specific reaction rates seen in these plots correspond to the overall ethanol conversion; their values apply to the determination of the activation energy of the reaction path of combustion because of the low quantities detected of secondary products, namely acetaldehyde and acetic acid. The Constable plot of apparent activation energies of ethanol combustion reaction over all the studied catalysts is presented in Fig. 8. A straight-line relationship between ln A and Ea was obtained, fitting the Cremer-Constable relation (ln Aapp =a Eapp +b), i.e. a compensation effect is evidenced, by carrying out the combustion of ethanol through the spinel systems considered in this work. It should be mentioned that a compensation effect was also found during oxidation of ethanol by several authors [43,44]. According to the analysis of Lynggaard et al. [45], a good agreement has been found between the average slope of the Constable plot ‘a’ and the value of the term (RT)−1. The temperature range in which measurements were carried out was 200–250°C assuming an average temperature of 225°C. The (RT)−1 term is 0.241molkJ−1, very close to the slope a of the Constable plot which was determined to be 0.251molkJ−1. 4 Discussion The less reactive catalyst CP-Co3-500 exhibited also the lowest surface area in comparison with the mixed oxides; this result is in agreement with previous studies [2,3]. According to the TPR results, the reduction of CP-Co2-500 sample occurs at higher temperatures than CP-Co1-500. An easy reducibility reflects directly the presence of surface defects and therefore oxygen mobility [46,47]. Consequently, an oxidation process (ethanol combustion in our case) was more difficult on the iron cobaltite catalyst than on the cobalt ferrite. A good correlation can therefore be established between the catalytic activity and the redox properties for the bulk catalysts. This result is in good agreement with those reported in the literature; indeed, several authors have related the catalysts activity to their reducibility in numerous studies as Mn-based catalysts for total oxidation of VOCs [48–51] and Co3O4/CeO2, Co3O4/CeO2–ZrO2 composite oxides in methane combustion [52]. Moreover, the reactivity of the spinel oxides has also been connected to the cationic distribution. Cobalt ferrite CoFe2O4 adopts an inverse spinel structure with a cationic distribution such that 80% of Co ions occupy octahedral sites [53–55], while FeCo2O4 is considered to be a normal spinel structure in which the octahedral sites are shared between cobalt and iron ions [56]. According to a number of papers, the octahedral sites are almost exclusively exposed on spinel crystallites surface and thus, the catalytic activity is mainly due to the octahedrally coordinated cations [57–59], implying that the catalytic activity can be improved on systems having active species located in octahedral sites. In a recent paper, we have attributed the catalytic activity of CoFe2O4 spinel oxide in the ethanol oxidation reaction to cobalt ions [32]. These species have the lower reduction temperatures in the Co-Fe-O systems and are therefore responsible for oxygen mobility on the crystallites surface. So, the weaker activity of FeCo2O4 compared with CoFe2O4 is certainly due to a less proportion of cobalt ions in octahedral sites and therefore the diminishing of the active species. A reversal reactivity order is observed between the supported iron cobaltite and the cobalt ferrite, compared with bulk catalysts but as the reducibility is also inverted as shown by TPR analysis, the correlation reducibility-catalytic activity is maintained. Moreover and unlike the bulk catalysts, the reactivity of IMP-Co3-500 is very close to that of IMP-Co1-500 as shown by the values of T90 summarized in Table 2. The difference between the T90 values is reduced from 62°C to 9°C by going from the bulk catalyst to the supported ones, although the IMP-Co3-500 BET surface area is lower than that of IMP-Co1-500 (Table 1). The present result implies that the reactivity of a single oxide can be comparable to that of a mixed oxide when they are both dispersed on a support; this improvement is certainly related to a similar dispersion of the active species on the support. It can be observed that the reactivity of a supported catalyst is clearly better than that of similar bulk. The active sites are certainly more accessible in the supported catalyst, due to a better dispersion of the active species on the surface of the support. This factor is usually in favor of the reactivity of a catalyst. Data from the literature relating to kinetic parameters of ethanol combustion reaction are generally rare and almost non-existent for the catalyst systems of spinel oxides. However, some authors report activation energy values that we took as a reference for comparison with our results. Delimaris and Ioannides [43,44] studied the combustion of ethanol over catalysts based on manganese, copper and cerium, with different molar ratios of Mn/Ce and Cu/Ce. The values of activation energy, as reported by these authors, are identified in the field 85–122kJ/mol for the Mn/Ce catalyst and 101–135kJ/mol for the Cu/Ce systems. Oyama et al. [60] report a value of 89kJ/mol, by carrying out the combustion of ethanol on manganese-based catalysts. By comparing the results obtained in this work with those found in the literature, it appears that spinel oxides are good candidates for catalyzing the ethanol combustion reaction; the values of the activation energies obtained are relatively low. 5 Conclusion CoxFe(3-x)O4 materials were synthesized as bulk and silica supported catalysts using co-precipitation and impregnation methods respectively. The results show that the operating conditions have a great effect on the structure and catalytic performance of the synthesized materials. For the bulk catalysts, cobalt oxide Co3O4 and cobalt ferrite CoFe2O4 powders display single spinel phases while iron cobaltite FeCo2O4 undergoes spinodal decomposition into two average compositional spinel phases between the cobalt ferrite CoFe2O4 and Co3O4 spinel oxide. The catalytic performance in the ethanol combustion of the mixed oxides CoFe2O4 and FeCo2O4 is generally better than that of the single oxide Co3O4 and cobalt ferrite exhibits the best activity. The catalytic activity was attributed to the Co2+ ions; the more easily they are reduce the more active is the solid in the ethanol combustion. The comparison of specific reaction rates indicated that the reactivity of a supported catalyst is clearly better than the corresponding bulk oxide. Moreover, the partial oxidation products namely acetaldehyde and acetic acid, are formed in lower amounts on the supported catalysts, indicating that supported catalysts orient further the reaction towards the total oxidation reaction. A kinetic study revealed that the values of the activation energies obtained are relatively low compared to those of literature. Besides compensation effect was evidenced during oxidation of ethanol with both the bulk and supported spinel oxides catalysts. References [1] F.I. Khan A.K. Ghosal J. Loss Prev. coredata.dc:description: Cobalt and mixed iron-cobalt spinel oxides CoxFe(3-x)O4 supported on SiO2 ‘IMP-Cox-500′ and their bulk analogues ‘CP-Cox-500′ were prepared via impregnation and co-precipitation methods respectively and calcined at 500°C. Thermogravimetric analysis ‘ATG/DTG’, X-ray Diffraction method ‘XRD’, Texture measurements ‘BET/BJH’ and Temperature Programmed Reduction technique ‘TPR’ were used for their characterization. Their catalytic behavior in ethanol combustion was investigated. Results showed that nanostructured oxide materials with spinel structure were obtained with a good dispersion of the active phase at the surface of silica in the case of IMP-Cox-500 compounds. The reduction behavior of the prepared samples is highly dependent on the oxide composition and interaction with the support; which is directly related to the catalytic behavior. The use of supported catalysts improves the catalytic performance and leads the reaction towards a total oxidation by decreasing greatly the formation of partial oxidation products. The obtained values of activation energies are relatively low in comparison with the literature data. A compensation effect was found by carrying out ethanol combustion through the spinel systems considered in this work.
coredata.dc:title: Cobalt and cobalt-iron spinel oxides as bulk and silica supported catalysts in the ethanol combustion reaction
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
